newsitem.title: SPAIN: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.
newsitem.headline: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.

text.p: Spanish government bonds drifted in thin trade on Monday, ending scarcely changed from Friday's closing levels with traders reluctant to enter the market ahead of the U.S. FOMC meeting on Tuesday.
A majority of analysts in a Reuters survey expect a 25 basis point hike in the U.S. 5.25 percent federal funds rate on Tuesday -- the first such move since February 1, 1995.
But despite market nerves, dealers said such a hike would fail to profoundly rattle bonds.
"If the Fed raises rates it will have a limited impact on the markets as it is already more or less factored in," one dealer said.
Dealers said the market was also quiet ahead of the Easter holidays.

Analysts said they did not expect any changes at the Bank of Spain's regular repo auction on Tuesday. A Reuters poll found that all 10 analysts believed the central bank would leave its key money rate unchanged at 5.75 percent.
The 10-year spread to Germany widened slightly to 127 basis points from 124 bps at Friday's close.
